content: The "Commuter Bill of Rights Act of 2010" defines terms like eligible recipient and public transportation, and establishes the Commuter Transit Rights Commission. The "Commuter Transit Rights Commission" is established to evaluate safety regulations for transit providers and make recommendations to the Secretary of Transportation. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by the Secretary within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The "Commuter Transit Rights Commission" consists of 12 members appointed by the Secretary of Transportation. Members include commuters of public transportation, rail safety experts, water transportation experts, State transportation agency employees, passenger safety experts, and emergency medicine experts. No Department of Transportation employee can serve on the Commission. The Chairperson is elected by members at the initial meeting, and each member serves for the life of the commission. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members are paid at a rate equal to the minimum annual rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule and receive travel expenses according to regulations. Recommendations for Federal regulations on commuter safety in an emergency situation must be approved by a majority of the Commission before inclusion in the Bill of Rights. The Commission will submit a supplemental report to the Secretary containing all recommendations considered, including those not included in the Bill of Rights. The Commission will terminate upon submission of the Bill of Rights and supplemental report to the Secretary. SEC. 4. GRANT PROGRAM. The Secretary may provide grants to public transportation providers for developing and implementing contingency plans that fulfill the Commuter Bill of Rights. Eligible recipients must submit an application within 90 days of the notice of availability, including a cost estimate for plan implementation. Providers must certify their commitment to implementing the contingency plan. The Secretary will implement the contingency plan within 90 days of receiving a grant. An eligible recipient can receive a grant of $50,000 or 50% of the total estimated costs for implementing the Commuter Bill of Rights, as determined by the Secretary. The Secretary will review and issue regulations for public transportation providers to comply with the standards of the Commuter Bill of Rights. Federal policies will be developed based on the Bill of Rights, including the submission of contingency plans meeting minimum standards, regular reviews and updates of plans, and compliance requirements for providers. Eligible recipients can receive grants for implementing the Commuter Bill of Rights. The Secretary will establish regulations for public transportation providers to comply with the Commuter Bill of Rights, including the submission of contingency plans, compliance requirements, and penalties for non-compliance. Additionally, a consumer hotline will be set up for addressing public transportation complaints within 30 days. Authorization of appropriations is granted to the Secretary to fund the implementation of this Act, with funds available until expended.
